case_name: State of Bombay v. Ratilal Vadilal Bros.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 429 of 1959 was filed by the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 429 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 6, 1957 of the former Bombay Sales Tax Tribunal in Appeal No.6 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 6, 1957 of the former Bombay Sales Tax Tribunal in Appeal No.6 of 1956.

facts.text: Sales Tax Tribunal allowed the appeal and set aside the order of the Collector of Sales Tax passed under s. 27 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: against an order of the Sales Tax Tribunal, Bombay, dated December 6, 1957, by which the Tribunal allowing the appeal before it, set aside an order of the Collector of Sales Tax passed under s. 27 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953.

facts.text: Respondents Ratilal Vadilal Bros. are commission agents doing business as clearing and transport contractors.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, Ratilal Vadilal Bros., are companymission agents doing business as clearing and transport companytractors.

facts.text: On June 25, 1954, respondents applied to the Collector of Sales Tax, Bombay, under ss. 27 a, b and c of the Act for determination whether they could be called dealers.

anchor.surface_text: On June 25, 1954, they applied to the Collector of Sales Tax, Bombay, under ss. 27 a ,  b  and  c  of the Act describing the nature of their business, citing one instance thereof, for determination of the question whether they companyld be called dealers within the Act.

facts.text: Collector held that respondents were dealers and required to register under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector by his order held that they were dealers, and were required to register themselves under the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal held that respondents were not dealers.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Tribunal held otherwise, and hence this appeal by the State of Bombay.

facts.text: No action was taken to ask for a reference to the High Court of Bombay under s. 34(1) read with ss. 30(1) and (2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that numberaction was taken to ask for a reference to the High Court of Bombay under s. 34 1  read with ss. 30 1  and  2  of the Act.

facts.text: The matter relates to a time after the Colliery Control Order, 1945 came into force.

anchor.surface_text: The matter relates to a time after the Colliery Control Order, 1945, came into force.

facts.text: Under Colliery Control Order, 1945, no person could acquire or purchase coal from a colliery except under authority of the Central Government with priority certificate from State Coal Controller.

anchor.surface_text: Under that Order, numberperson companyld acquire or purchase companyl from a companyliery except under authority of the Central Government for which purpose he had to obtain a priority certificate from the State Coal Controller.

facts.text: Del credere agents were allowed to act and charge a commission of one rupee per ton of coal under the Control Order.

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme of the Order, del credere agents were allowed to act and to charge a companymission of one rupee per ton of companyl.

facts.text: Nanalal Karsandas, a brick manufacturer, was allotted a priority certificate for 22 tons of coal on June 17, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: One Nanalal Karsandas, a brick manufacturer, was allotted a priority certificate in respect of 22 tons of companyl on June 17, 1954.

facts.text: Nanalal Karsandas dealt with M s. S.C. Rungta Colliery, Burhar, through the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: He dealt with M s. S.C. Rungta Colliery, Burhar, through the respondents.

facts.text: Consignment was in the name of Karsandas, but the bill was sent by the Colliery to the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The companysignment was in the name of Karsandas, but the bill was sent by the Colliery to the respondents, and the respondents, in their turn, made out a bill

facts.text: Respondents made out a bill to Karsandas charging the amount of the Colliery bill plus Rs. 22 as commission.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondents, in their turn, made out a bill in which they charged, in addition to the amount of the bill of the Colliery, a sum of Rs. 22 as their companymission.

facts.text: Liability to pay the Colliery rested upon the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The liability to pay the Colliery rested upon the respondents, but they claimed to be acting as mere middlemen between the Colliery and Karsandas.

facts.text: Respondents claimed to be acting as mere middlemen between the Colliery and Karsandas.

anchor.surface_text: but they claimed to be acting as mere middlemen between the Colliery and Karsandas. The respondents stated that their business was along these lines with other companystituents also,

facts.text: Priority certificate produced in the case was made out in the name of the respondents but shows the consumer as the consignee.

anchor.surface_text: The certificate which has been produced in the case, though made out in the name of the respondents, shows the companysumer as the companysignee.

facts.text: There was no sale by the Colliery to the respondents, but directly to Karsandas through the agency of the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus plain that there was numbersale by the Colliery to the respondents, but directly to Karsan- das, though through the agency of the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents' bill to Karsandas mentioned he was the consignee and they charged only middlemen commission.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents also, when they made out the bill to Karsandas, mentioned that he was the companysignee, and that they were only charging their middlemen companymission.

facts.text: There were no two sales; only one sale by the Colliery to the consumer.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, it is difficult to hold that the Colliery sold companyl to the respondents, and that they, in turn, sold it to Karsandas. There were numbertwo sales involved there was only one sale,

facts.text: Respondents never became owners by purchase from the Colliery because they had no certificate.

anchor.surface_text: and that was by the Colliery to the companysumer. The respondents never became owners by purchase from the Colliery, because the Colliery would number have sold companyl to them, number companyld they have bought it unless they had obtained a certificate.

facts.text: Position of respondents was merely that of agents arranging sale to disclosed purchaser, guaranteeing payment.

anchor.surface_text: The position of the respondents was merely that of agents, arranging the sale to a disclosed purchaser, though guaranteeing payment to the Colliery on behalf of their principal.

issues.text: whether to invoke the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136 without first exhausting all remedies

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, this Court will number allow the High Court to be bypassed in this manner, and the proper course for an appellant is to exhaust all his remedies before invoking the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136. In the present case, however, the matter is simple, and the learned companynsel for the respondent requested us to determine the question, stating that his client who was a small trader and who made the application for the clarification of the law, would be dragged through Courts once again, if we were to decide this appeal on this short point.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agreed to decide despite non-exhaustion of remedies.

arguments.claim: Ordinarily, appellants must exhaust all remedies including reference to High Court under s.34(1) read with ss.30(1),(2) before invoking Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that no action was taken to ask for a reference to the High Court of Bombay under s. 34(1) read with ss. 30(1) and (2) of the Act. We have frequently noticed that all the remedies which are open to an appellant are not first exhausted before moving this Court. Ordinarily, this Court will not allow the High Court to be bypassed in this manner, and the proper course for an appellant is to exhaust all his remedies before invoking the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136.

arguments.claim: Dealer means any person who carries on the business of selling goods in the State of Bombay, whether for commission, remuneration or otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Dealer in the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953, is defined as follows dealer means any person who carries on the business of selling goods in the State of Bombay, whether for commission, remuneration or otherwise

arguments.claim: The question is whether the respondents were carrying on the business of selling coal.

anchor.surface_text: The short question in this case, therefore, was whether the respondents were carrying on such a business in respect of coal.

arguments.claim: Under Colliery Control Order, 1945, no person could acquire or purchase coal from a colliery except under authority of Central Government with priority certificate; del credere agents allowed to charge commission.

anchor.surface_text: Under that Order, no person could acquire or purchase coal from a colliery except under authority of the Central Government for which purpose he had to obtain a priority certificate from the State Coal Controller. Under the scheme of the Order, del credere agents were allowed to act and to charge a commission of one rupee per ton of coal.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have said, no business of selling coal was disclosed in the instance cited before the Collector, and the order of the Tribunal was correct on the facts placed before it.

holdings.text: In the present case, however, the matter is simple, and the learned counsel for the respondent requested us to determine the question, stating that his client who was a small trader and who made the application for the clarification of the law, would be dragged through Courts once again, if we were to decide this appeal on this short point. In view of this, though we decide this appeal, we must not be held to lay down a cursus curiae for this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, this Court will number allow the High Court to be bypassed in this manner, and the proper course for an appellant is to exhaust all his remedies before invoking the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136. anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, this Court will number allow the High Court to be bypassed in this manner, and the proper course for an appellant is to exhaust all his remedies before invoking the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136. In the present case, however, the matter is simple, and the learned companynsel for the respondent requested us to determine the question, stating that his client who was a small trader and who made the application for the clarification of the law, would be dragged through Courts once again, if we were to decide this appeal on this short point.
In view of what we have said, numberbusiness of selling companyl was disclosed in the instance cited before the Collector, and the order of the Tribunal was companyrect on the facts placed before it.
